articles.headline: White House and G.O.P. Close In on Deal to Raise Debt Limit and Cut Spending
articles.snippet: The details were not finalized, but negotiators were discussing a compromise that would allow Republicans to point to spending reductions and Democrats to say they had prevented large cuts.
articles.abstract: The details were not finalized, but negotiators were discussing a compromise that would allow Republicans to point to spending reductions and Democrats to say they had prevented large cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Top White House officials and Republican lawmakers were closing in Thursday on a deal that would raise the debt limit for two years while imposing strict caps on discretionary spending not related to the military or veterans for the same period. Officials were racing to cement an agreement in time to avert a federal default that is projected in just one week.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Brands Embracing Pride Month Confront a Volatile Political Climate
articles.snippet: Target became the latest company to adjust plans for marketing supportive of the L.G.B.T.Q. community after it faced backlash from some customers.
articles.abstract: Target became the latest company to adjust plans for marketing supportive of the L.G.B.T.Q. community after it faced backlash from some customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Pride Month, the annual celebration for L.G.B.T.Q. Americans, has afforded companies a marketing opportunity to tap into the buying power of a group with growing financial, political and social clout.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Oath Keepers Leader Is Sentenced to 18 Years in Jan. 6 Sedition Case
articles.snippet: The sentence for Stewart Rhodes was the longest so far in the federal investigation of the Capitol attack and the first issued to a defendant convicted of sedition.
articles.abstract: The sentence for Stewart Rhodes was the longest so far in the federal investigation of the Capitol attack and the first issued to a defendant convicted of sedition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the far-right Oath Keepers militia, was sentenced on Thursday to 18 years in prison for his conviction on seditious conspiracy charges for the role he played in helping to mobilize the pro-Trump attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

articles.headline: Leaders Let Problems Mount at Brutal SEAL Course, Navy Finds
articles.snippet: Overzealous instructors, unchecked drug use, and inadequate leadership and medical oversight turned a tough selection course into a dangerous ordeal, investigators found.
articles.abstract: Overzealous instructors, unchecked drug use, and inadequate leadership and medical oversight turned a tough selection course into a dangerous ordeal, investigators found.
articles.lead_paragraph: The notoriously grueling Navy SEAL selection course grew so tough in recent years that to attempt it became dangerous, even deadly. With little oversight, instructors pushed their classes to exhaustion. Students began dropping out in large numbers, or turning to illegal drugs to try to keep up.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Faces Reckoning for Long Ties With Jeffrey Epstein
articles.snippet: Two lawsuits claim that the nation’s largest bank ignored signs about Jeffrey Epstein’s sex trafficking because it was profiting from its relationship with him.
articles.abstract: Two lawsuits claim that the nation’s largest bank ignored signs about Jeffrey Epstein’s sex trafficking because it was profiting from its relationship with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Epstein was many things: a sexual predator, a friend to the rich and powerful and, for many years, a lucrative customer of the nation’s largest bank.

articles.headline: Hundreds of Thousands Have Lost Medicaid Coverage Since Pandemic Protections Expired
articles.snippet: As states begin to drop people from their Medicaid programs, early data shows that many recipients are losing their coverage for procedural reasons.
articles.abstract: As states begin to drop people from their Medicaid programs, early data shows that many recipients are losing their coverage for procedural reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of low-income Americans have lost Medicaid coverage in recent weeks as part of a sprawling unwinding of a pandemic-era policy that prohibited states from removing people from the program.

articles.headline: Predawn Picket Lines Help Writers Disrupt Studio Productions
articles.snippet: Workers from other unions have shown solidarity with the strikers, catching entertainment companies off guard.
articles.abstract: Workers from other unions have shown solidarity with the strikers, catching entertainment companies off guard.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 5 a.m. on a recent weekday, a lone figure paced back and forth outside the main entrance to the Fox Studios lot in Los Angeles. Peter Chiarelli, a screenwriter, was walking the picket line.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling and John Koblin

articles.headline: This Little-Known Pandemic-Era Tax Credit Has Become a Magnet for Fraud
articles.snippet: The Employee Retention Credit has spawned a cottage industry of firms claiming to help businesses get stimulus funds, often in violation of federal rules.
articles.abstract: The Employee Retention Credit has spawned a cottage industry of firms claiming to help businesses get stimulus funds, often in violation of federal rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early February, federal prosecutors in Utah accused Zachary Bassett and Mason Warr of cheating the United States government out of millions of dollars. The accounting firm they operated had submitted more than 1,000 fraudulent tax forms to the Internal Revenue Service on behalf of businesses trying to claim pandemic-era stimulus funds, the prosecutors said.

articles.headline: Colleges Will Be Able to Hide a Student’s Race on Admissions Applications
articles.snippet: If requested, the Common App will conceal basic information on race and ethnicity — a move that could help schools if the Supreme Court ends affirmative action.
articles.abstract: If requested, the Common App will conceal basic information on race and ethnicity — a move that could help schools if the Supreme Court ends affirmative action.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each year, the million or so students applying to college through the Common App are given the option to check a box, disclosing whether they identify as Hispanic, Asian, Black or white, among other choices.
